chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should aim to make presidential elections reflect the voters more closely while keeping states meaningfully involved and avoiding sudden, destabilizing change. A workable compromise is to keep the Electoral College but require proportional elector allocation in every state, combined with a national floor for election administration (ballot access, transparent audits, and standardized recount triggers) so results are comparable and trusted. This would reduce winner-take-all distortions, broaden where candidates campaign, and protect confidence that both populous and smaller states are treated fairly.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform the Electoral College to better reflect the nationwide popular will while preserving states’ role and the legitimacy of a federal system. A practical path is to reduce winner-take-all distortions—through proportional or district-based allocation with strong anti-gerrymandering safeguards—or to adopt a National Popular Vote Interstate Compact once clear, auditable national standards for ballot access, counting, recounts, and deadlines are in place. Any changes should be phased in lawfully, require electors to follow the voters, and be designed to push candidates to compete beyond a handful of battleground states while strengthening trust for urban, suburban, and rural communities alike.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A workable reform should keep the Electoral College’s federal-state role while reducing winner-take-all distortions so more voters and communities feel heard. States could move to proportional or district-based elector allocation with strong anti-gerrymandering rules, alongside clear nationwide standards for voter eligibility, ballot access, audits, and recount deadlines to improve trust. If broader agreement is possible, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact could be phased in only after those integrity and transparency safeguards are in place.
